gear.name: Base Layer (Mid-Weight Synthetic)
gear.description: Mid-weight underwear top made of wool, synthetic, or Capilene

gear.name: Middle Layer (Fleece Pullover)
gear.description: Polyester fleece pullover/expedition weight top of PolartecÂ® 100 or 200, or a wool sweater.

gear.name: Top Layer (Synthetic Jacket)
gear.description: A warm, synthetic jacket-filled jacket that fits over your base layers.

gear.name: Wind Shirt
gear.description: A lightweight, breathable, durable nylon wind shell in either pullover or parka style.

gear.name: Rain Jacket
gear.description: A sturdy, roomy waterproof jacket with a hood.

gear.name: T-Shirt
gear.description: A lightweight polyester, wool / CapileneÂ® T- shirt.

gear.name: Long Underwear (Mid-Weight Synthetic)
gear.description: A lightweight polyester, wool / CapileneÂ® T- shirt.

gear.name: Puffy Pants
gear.description: Expedition-weight bottoms that fit comfortably over the under layer bottoms.

gear.name: Wind Pants
gear.description: Nylon shell pants. These should fit comfortably over all lower-body layers.

gear.name: Nylon Shorts
gear.description: Loose-fitting nylon athletic/river shorts.

gear.name: Underwear
gear.description: Optional.

gear.name: Baseball Cap/Sun Hat
gear.description: To protect ears and face from the sun.

gear.name: Balaclava/Buff
gear.description: Balaclavas are full head and neck coverings that have an opening for the face.

gear.name: Wool or Fleece Hat
gear.description: A hat to to keep you warm at night.

gear.name: Gloves
gear.description: Ragg wool or synthetic

gear.name: Backpack
gear.description: 85 liters (or less depending on your trip length/preference)

gear.name: Small Stuff Sacks
gear.description: 2 or 3 small nylon or mesh sacks for organizing items in your pack.

gear.name: Food Zip Bag
gear.description: A lightweight bag to store your food.

gear.name: Tent
gear.description: Backpacking tent (ie Tarptent Double Rainbow)

gear.name: Camp Stove
gear.description: Lightweight backpacking stove. Spatula, lighter and pot grips should be stored inside.

gear.name: Fuel and Fuel Bottles
gear.description: Depends on the stove

gear.name: Pan
gear.description: Cooking pan (Frybakes are great for gourmet cooking).

gear.name: Pot
gear.description: Cooking pot

gear.name: Trowels or Shovels
gear.description: Leave no trace ðŸ’©

gear.name: Maps amd Compass
gear.description: USGS Topos and a good compass

gear.name: Bincoculars
gear.description: They're nice to have!

gear.name: First Aid Kit
gear.description: Important to have in the Wilderness

gear.name: Equipment repair kit
gear.description: Sometimes stuff breaks

gear.name: Sleeping Bag
gear.description: Synthetic-filled bags (QuallofilÂ®, HollofilÂ®, PolarguardÂ®, etc.) perform well in the variety of conditions we encounter on courses. A bag with approximately 3 pounds of fill rated to 5Â° or 10Â° F.

gear.name: Summit/Compression Pack
gear.description: We use the Lowe Attack Summit that doubles as a compression stuff sack for your sleeping bag and a summit pack for day hikes

gear.name: Plastic Trash Bags
gear.description: Heavy-duty lawn and garden bags (33 gallon) to help waterproof your sleeping bag and backpack.

gear.name: Sleeping Pad
gear.description: Should be closed-cell foam and 3/8" thick. Used for padding and insulation between sleeping bag and ground. We highly recommend and sell self-inflating sleeping mat as one of your pads. Thermarest and Insulmat are great brands.

gear.name: Insulated Mug
gear.description: 20 oz. insulated mugs with lids are preferred.

gear.name: Bowl
gear.description: A bowl with a snap-on lid is handy.

gear.name: Spoon
gear.description: Lexan spoons are light, durable and popular

gear.name: Water Bottle
gear.description: Wide-mouth liter-size plastic bottle, like NalgeneÂ® bottle.

gear.name: Lip Balm
gear.description: Stick, cream, or tube type moisturizing balm with sun protection factor (SPF) 15 or greater

gear.name: Sunscreen
gear.description: A 6 ounce tube with sun protection factor (SPF) 15 or greater

gear.name: Bandana
gear.description: A few of these are always handy.

gear.name: Head-Lamp
gear.description: Durable and lightweight. Headlamps are popular. Bring spare batteries.

gear.name: Disposable Lighters
gear.description: Use for lighting your camp stove.

gear.name: Insect Repellent
gear.description: 1-2 small bottles. No aerosol spray cans.

gear.name: Watch
gear.description: A watch with an alarm is a nice feature.

gear.name: Notepad And Pencil
gear.description: A small, lightweight pad is fine.

gear.name: Sunglass Retainer
gear.description: Optional. ChumsÂ® or CroakiesÂ® for keeping track of your glasses or sunglasses.

gear.name: Sunglasses
gear.description: Any good quality sunglasses with 100% UV protection will work fine.

gear.name: Instant Hand Sanitizer
gear.description: Must have 2 oz. bottles for keeping hands clean.

gear.name: Pocket Knife
gear.description: One small knife is sufficient; simple Swiss Army knives are popular.

gear.name: Boots
gear.description: Sturdy leather heavy backpacking or light mountaineering boots with good ankle support.

gear.name: Socks
gear.description: Heavy ragg wool or heavy wool/synthetic blend.

gear.name: Liner Socks
gear.description: Optional. Lightweight wool, synthetic or CapileneÂ® "wick dry" socks. You will need at least two pairs if you are using a liner sock/wool sock combination in your hiking boots.

gear.name: Gaiters
gear.description: Knee high, durable.

gear.name: Camp Shoes
gear.description: Running, tennis, or cross-training athletic shoes.

gear.name: Binoculars
gear.description: Small travel binoculars work well.

gear.name: Prescription Glasses And Contact Lenses
gear.description: If you wear them, bring a spare pair of glasses or lenses. Contact lens wearers should also bring a pair of glasses as backup. Again, prescription sunglasses are a nice item to have in reserve.

gear.name: Water Treatment
gear.description: Potable Aqua tablets (hydroperiodide) or Aqua Mira for backcountry water purification. However, if you are sensitive to iodine or chlorine you may need to bring your water filter such as the PUR Scout or Hiker, or the SWEETWATER Guardian.

gear.name: Vitamins
gear.description: Not necessary, but a small quantity of multivitamins is popular among hikers

gear.name: Book
gear.description: A small paperback reading book.

gear.name: Trekking Poles
gear.description: A sturdy 2-3 section pole for easy packing

gear.name: Camera
gear.description: Lightweight, 35 mm compact cameras are sufficient; bring a protective case. Avoid heavy lenses and elaborate set-ups.

gear.name: Backpackerâ€™s Camp Chair
gear.description: Crazy Creek or one with Therm-A-Rest fitting.

gear.name: Hydration System
gear.description: Very handy and popular.
